Ken,

Thank you again for your reply.  I really appreciate it.  I will thin=
k over the different issues.


Jim


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From=
: Kenneth Stanley 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, July 28, =
2004 4:00 PM
  Subject: [neat] Re: An ANN design question...


  --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
  > 
  > So my questions are this=
:
  > A) What is the theoretical or mathematical explanation as to why 
  t=
he input values for NEAT are
  > pushed through an input node's activation =
function as opposed
  to 
  being used directly?
  > B) Does some form of a=
ssumption exist in which to provide input to 
  a NEAT ANN, the input data
=
  > point for each input node must be scaled such that the data 
  point's =
relevant range of values falls
  > between the upper and lower bounds of th=
e input node's
  activation 
  function?
  > C) What kinds of different typ=
es of activation functions on an 
  input node might possibly handle
  > th=
is differently and/or more effectively?
  > 
  > Sidenote: In SEMIANN, I do=
 not allow a connection to have a 
  destination of an input node.  So
  > =
there is no need for an activation function at an input node.  And 
  input=
 node is treated as just
  > an unbounded data point.  It was my understand=
ing that if there 
  was to be feedback to the "input",
  > it would occur =
as new nodes and connections around the 
  hidden/output nodes from which t=
he
  > particular input node was connected.
  > 
  > Well, that sort of too=
k much longer to present than I initially 
  thought.  Hmmm.
  > 
  > Thank=
 you for any clarification(s) you can offer on this.
  > 
  > 


  Hey Jim,=
  

  I will try to respond more thoroughly now that I've submitted my 
  d=
issertation, although it looks like people on the list have already 
  work=
ed through these issues.  But as I said before, my 
  implementation of NEA=
T does not run inputs through any kind of 
  activation function, so in fac=
t I agree with you on everything here.

  On the other hand, running inputs=
 through an activation can be seen 
  as just one of many possible ways of =
scaling or normalizing inputs 
  to get them in the best form for an ANN.  =
In that sense, maybe in 
  some cases there is a good intuition behind doin=
g it, but on the 
  face of it, it does seem ad hoc to me, i.e. why use a s=
igmoid of all 
  possible methods for normalization?  

  Still, normalizat=
ion in the broader sense is a good idea. (This sort 
  of answers part C of=
 your question.)  So in other words, if there is 
  an input that naturtall=
y varies from 0 to 1,000,000, you proabably 
  want to compress that range =
a lot sending it into the net.  So 
  the "activation function" would be th=
e function that compresses the 
  range.  But that really shouldn't be call=
ed an "activation 
  function," since it's really just data preprocessing, =
and also 
  because different inputs in the same net probably should be 
  =
normalized in different ways.

  Anyway, I have probably been redundant wit=
h some of the stuff in 
  this long thread, but I wanted to try to answer s=
ince I said I would 
  before when I was too swamped.

  ken
